# Timeline {background-color="#62259D"}


## Timeline



<br>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" }

[Karl Marx]{.note} (1818&mdash;1883)

![](young.png){fig-align="left" width="300" height="400"}

:::


::: {.column width="50%"}


::: {style="font-size: 85%"}

- 1818: Born in [Trier]{.note}, state of Prussia.

- 1835: Entered [law]{.note} school, University of Bonn.

- 1836: Transferred to University of Berlin.

- 1839: Switched to [Philosophy]{.note}, defended his thesis (on Greek philosophy, U. of Jena) with the goal of becoming a university lecturer.

- 1841: [Journalism]{.note} career: *Deutsche Jahrbücher* and *Rheinische Zeitung*.

- 1842: First meeting with [Friedrich Engels]{.note}.

- 1843: [Marriage]{.note} to Jenny von Westphalen.

- 1843: Moves to [Paris]{.note}; founds *Deutsch-Franzosische Jahrbücher*.

- 1844: Publication of *Introduction to A Critique of Hegel’s Philosophy of Right* and writes *Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts*.

:::

## Intellectual influences


:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}

[Ludwig Feuerbach]{.note} (1804&mdash;1872)

![](feuerbach.png){fig-align="left" width="300" height="400"}


:::


::: {.column width="50%" .incremental}

::: {style="font-size: 80%"}

- [Religious differences]{.note} as an impediment to German [unification.]{.note}

- *"God, as the Father, is the generator, the active, the principle of **masculine** spontaneity [...]"* (p. 71)

- *"The Father is a truth only where the Mother is a truth. Love is in and by itself essentially feminine in its nature. The belief in the love of God is the belief in the **feminine** principle as divine. Love apart from living nature is an anomaly, a phantom. Behold in love the holy necessity and depth of Nature!"* (p. 72)

- *"Thus the material of baptism is water, common, natural water, just as the material of religion in general is common, natural humanity. But as religion **alienates** our own nature from us, and represents it as not ours, so the water of baptism is regarded as quite other than common water ; for it has not a physical but a hyperphysical power and significance."* (p. 236)



- [Atheism]{.note} as a solution.

:::

# Why Political Economy? {background-color="#62259D"}


## Why Political Economy?

<br>

February 1844: 

- Publication of [Introduction]{.note} to *A Critique of Hegel’s Philosophy of Right*.

. . .

<br>

[Structure]{.note} of Feuerbach's system, but with [different elements]{.note}.


## Why Political Economy?

<br>

Summer 1844: 

- Writing of the *Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts* (only coming to the general public in the 1930s).

. . .


<br>

The central theme: [alienated]{.note} ([estranged]{.note}) labor.
